Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of a Pilot Microfactory for Nanomedicine Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The project will produce advances in the science and engineering of micro-fabrication technology and the utilization of nanoscale materials to build medical micro-devices. The research facility will provide engineers with prototyping tools and nanoscale materials needed to reproducibly build miniature devices. The devices will allow investigating new approaches to medical science and enable critical in vivo measurements never made before. The facility offers researchers a means to economically prototype next-generation devices and to incorporate nanotechnology into biology and medicine. The first nanomaterials to be used in the facility will be CNT arrays, ribbon, and yarn (that are already available at UC) as well as commercially available magnetic nanoparticles. CNT thread, made using cm long nanotubes, will be lightweight, stronger than steel, pliable, inert, nontoxic, and electrically and thermally conductive. Initial devices to be fabricated will utilize these materials for miniature carbon electronics, electric motors, actuators, carbon wire, sensors, antennae, and actuators for inside and outside the body. These microdevices will monitor and repair the body in ways that were not possible before.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Pilot Microfactory for Nanomedicine devics (Fig-1) is being used to develop nanomanufacturing based macro-assembled nanoscale materials (Fig-2) and tiny machines (Fig-3) to work inside the human body. The materials developed include polymer coated carbon nanoube yarn and tape with integrated copper and other nanoparticles, and electro-magnetic elastomers. The tiny machines currently being developed comprise tethered self-propelled robots and robots attached to a flexible arm. Nano-induction motors, fractal antennas, micro-biosensors and supercapacitors are other devices being built in the microfactory.   

These tiny machines will work inside the human body to improve present treatments such as cardiovascular procdures and may diagnose and treat diseases such as certain cancers for which no definite cure is currently known (Fig-4). Versatile smart surgcal tools being developed will take biopsies, deliver drugs, releases adhesions, and execute reconstructive surgery with less damage to the body.

Overall, the NSF Pilot Microfactory is an assembly of high technology characterizaton and manipulation instruments integrated togther to facilitate building prototpye devices such as smart surgical tools that will improve medical procedures and thus address the national grand challenge to upgrade our healthcare system. Carbon nanotubes with copper and other embedded nanoparticles will become the next generaton of electric machines (Fig-5) and electrical conductors for in vivo medical applications and also for widespread engineering applications. Flexible electromagnetic actuators will enable milli-robots and other tiny devices to be small enough and flexible enough for use inside the body. Flexible actuators will also find uses in smart structures such as metamorphic vehicles that cheat the wind.

Past efforts at building tiny machines were rolling in the deep because we did not have the proper materials and manufacturing methods. Now, with nanotechnology and nanomedicne, there is hope that we can have it all - new precison medical devices that are a life-saving option for patients where traditional drugs, surgery, or radiation therapies do not work.


Last Modified: 05/30/2016
Modified by: Mark J Schulz

    David Mast, Richard Kleismit, Vesselin Shanov, Sumeet Chaudhary, Noe Alvarez, Guangfeng Hou, Yi Song, Dineshwaran Vijayakumar, John Yin, Sarah Pixley, Kevin Haworth, Mark Schulz, University of Cincinnati; Jeb Head, Atkins & Pearce Company

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: A Pilot Microfactory for Nanomedicine devics (Fig-1) is being used to develop nanomanufacturing based macro-assembled nanoscale materials (Fig-2) and tiny machines (Fig-3) to work inside the human body. The materials developed include polymer coated carbon nanoube yarn and tape with integrated copper and other nanoparticles, and electro-magnetic elastomers. The tiny machines currently being developed comprise tethered self-propelled robots and robots attached to a flexible arm. Nano-induction motors, fractal antennas, micro-biosensors and supercapacitors are other devices being built in the microfactory. These tiny machines will work inside the human body to improve present treatments such as cardiovascular procdures and may diagnose and treat diseases such as certain cancers for which no definite cure is currently known (Fig-4). Versatile smart surgcal tools being developed will take biopsies, deliver drugs, releases adhesions, and execute reconstructive surgery with less damage to the body. Overall, the NSF Pilot Microfactory is an assembly of high technology characterizaton and manipulation instruments integrated togther to facilitate building prototpye devices such as smart surgical tools that will improve medical procedures and thus address the national grand challenge to upgrade our healthcare system. Carbon nanotubes with copper and other embedded nanoparticles will become the next generaton of electric machines (Fig-5) and electrical conductors for in vivo medical applications and also for widespread engineering applications. Flexible electromagnetic actuators will enable milli-robots and other tiny devices to be small enough and flexible enough for use inside the body. Flexible actuators will also find uses in smart structures such as metamorphic vehicles that cheat the wind. Past efforts at building tiny machines were rolling in the deep because we did not have the proper materials and manufacturing methods. Now, with nanotechnology and nanomedicne, there is hope that we can have it all - new precison medical devices that are a life-saving option for patients where traditional drugs, surgery, or radiation therapies do not work.
